content.raw:
I solved it.

You need to change  ~/.ignition/fuel/config.yaml as following.

-    url: https://api.ignitionfuel.org

to

+    url: https://api.ignitionrobotics.org

Best,
content.html:
I solved it.

You need to change ~/.ignition/fuel/config.yaml as following.

  • url: https://api.ignitionfuel.org

to

  • url: https://api.ignitionrobotics.org

Best,

content.raw:
Perfect. Thanks very much!

I actually have a second error in there, the last line reads:

VMware: vmw_ioctl_command error Invalid argument.

This is because I am running gazebo in VMware. Anyway, to solve this you should turn off 3d acceleration in vmware.

content.raw:
It worth to mention here that this problems affects the 9.0.0 version of Gazebo supplied by Ubuntu official repositories. Newer versions of gazebo9 available in the [packages.osrfoundation.org](http://packages.osrfoundation.org) repositories does not suffer from it. The [step by step instructions ](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?cat=install&tut=install_ubuntu&ver=9.0#Alternativeinstallation:step-by-step)provides a good way to upgrade the packages using our repositories.

Not a fix but a possible workaround.
content.html:
It worth to mention here that this problems affects the 9.0.0 version of Gazebo supplied by Ubuntu official repositories. Newer versions of gazebo9 available in the packages.osrfoundation.org repositories does not suffer from it. The step by step instructions provides a good way to upgrade the packages using our repositories.

Not a fix but a possible workaround.

content.raw: Would it be possible to setup a redirect on the server so that the old endpoint redirected to the new one?
content.html: Would it be possible to setup a redirect on the server so that the old endpoint redirected to the new one?

content.raw: Even if we set a redirect, Gazebo 9.0.0 won't be able to follow it because of how it's using CURL. See [this answer](https://answers.gazebosim.org/question/20706/gazebo7-hangs-on-downloading-models/?answer=20724#post-id-20724) about a similar issue.
content.html: Even if we set a redirect, Gazebo 9.0.0 won't be able to follow it because of how it's using CURL. See this answer about a similar issue.

content.raw:
@{557058:6ff86fcb-b7ab-44a5-b8a6-f6d9cae8b6e8} Thanks, I’ll work around this for now by not using the version in the Ubuntu package repository as suggested by @{557058:155a32e2-420c-4d50-98e0-0e722f63f906}   
  
But if it can’t be fixed, and this ticket has priority “minor” then perhaps the best “fix” would be to update the documentation with a warning to users trying to use the package from the debian repositories and then close this ticket as “won’t fix”.  
  
It’s odd that something which prevents the program from starting out of the box on Ubuntu when installed directly from Ubuntu is considered minor. Are the debian/ubuntu hosted packages officially deprecated? This might be important information in case IT departments care where packages are being installed from.  
  
I see the installation tutorials give the instructions to install from the osrf repository, but it does not appear to warn against using the version in the official packages, or give a post-install steps for those who do install from the Ubuntu packages.  
  
[http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install\_ubuntu&cat=install](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_ubuntu&cat=install)

```diff
Install Gazebo using Ubuntu packages

This tutorial covers the installation of Gazebo packages using the the osrfoundation.org repository, designed for those who want to follow the faster development path but still a stable one.

- Gazebo is also released as an Ubuntu official package: (check which version is available for every distribution. If you are a ROS user, please read the tutorial about ROS/Gazebo installation.
+ Although Gazebo is also released as an Ubuntu official package it is not recommended: (check which version is available for every distribution. If you are a ROS user, please read the tutorial about ROS/Gazebo installation.
```

or 

```diff
- Gazebo is also released as an Ubuntu official package: (check which version is available for every distribution. If you are a ROS user, please read the tutorial about ROS/Gazebo installation.
+ Gazebo is also released as an Ubuntu official package, but may require some post installation steps see LINK: (check which version is available for every distribution. If you are a ROS user, please read the tutorial about ROS/Gazebo installation.
```

  
\(Sorry unfamiliar with the Bitbucket diff code-block syntax those might not look correct\)

content.raw:
> It’s odd that something which prevents the program from starting out of the box on Ubuntu when installed directly from Ubuntu is considered minor

This issue shouldn't in any way prevent Gazebo from starting out of the box. This issue has only 2 consequences:

1. Models can't be pulled directly from Ignition Fuel (beta feature)
1. An error message is printed:

```
[Err] [REST.cc:205] Error in REST request

libcurl: (51) SSL: no alternative certificate subject name matches target host name 'api.ignitionfuel.org'
```

Gazebo should be fully functional otherwise. I believe you may be conflating a different issue with this one.

> Are the debian/ubuntu hosted packages officially deprecated?

Nope, I just tested them here and they work fine except for the caveats above.

> close this ticket

This sounds reasonable to me. The issue has been fixed on later Gazebo 9 minor versions.

For Gazebo 9.0.0, which is the version upstream on Ubuntu Bionic, there's a workaround, which is to change the URL on `~/.ignition/fuel/config.yaml`:

```.diff
-     url: https://api.ignitionfuel.org
+     url: https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org
```

Note that Ubuntu Focal will ship with a later minor version of Gazebo 9 so this issue will be solved out of the box.

  1. Models can't be pulled directly from Ignition Fuel (beta feature)
  2. An error message is printed:
[Err] [REST.cc:205] Error in REST request

libcurl: (51) SSL: no alternative certificate subject name matches target host name 'api.ignitionfuel.org'

Gazebo should be fully functional otherwise. I believe you may be conflating a different issue with this one.

Are the debian/ubuntu hosted packages officially deprecated?

Nope, I just tested them here and they work fine except for the caveats above.

close this ticket

This sounds reasonable to me. The issue has been fixed on later Gazebo 9 minor versions.

For Gazebo 9.0.0, which is the version upstream on Ubuntu Bionic, there's a workaround, which is to change the URL on ~/.ignition/fuel/config.yaml:

-     url: https://api.ignitionfuel.org
+     url: https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org

Note that Ubuntu Focal will ship with a later minor version of Gazebo 9 so this issue will be solved out of the box.
